Stem: Alpha Standardized Science G8.7 Created By STC 11 Which characteristic of an extinct organism makes it best suited to be used as an index fossil?
Choices: A) an organism whose fossils show evolutionary change over time, B) an organism that was commonly only in specific types of environments, C) an organism that was commonly fossilized during a specific period of time, D) an organism whose fossils are found in rocks ranging in age from ancient to recent times Giselle makes a model, using foam balls, to represent the events in a solar eclipse. To demonstrate this phenomenon
Scenario Justification: Real-world reference provides some context but limited uncertainty.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Recall/identification only.
DCI Justification: DCI present but used at surface level — identification rather than reasoning.
CCC Justification: Structure-function relationship implicitly present.
Key Recommendation: Add a real-world phenomenon or puzzling scenario that students need to figure out. Require students to engage in a science practice (analyze data, construct explanation, argue from evidence).

Stem: Giselle makes a model, using foam balls, to represent the events in a solar eclipse. To demonstrate this phenomenon best, the foam ball model should have which characteristic?
Choices: A) city wants to build a new concert hall. They want to avoid echoes and background noises., B) the ability of balls to revolve around each other, C) a source of light within each ball, D) a different color for each ball
Scenario Justification: Visual provided but limited scenario context. Somewhat guided.
SEP Justification: Uses a model but at mechanical/reading level, not for sense-making.
DCI Justification: Some content engagement in answer choices but limited reasoning with DCI.
CCC Justification: Structure-function relationship implicitly present.
Key Recommendation: Add a real-world phenomenon or puzzling scenario that students need to figure out. Require students to engage in a science practice (analyze data, construct explanation, argue from evidence).

Stem: up the weather in London every day for one month. At the end of this time, will the students have enough data to determine the climate of London?
Choices: A) Yes, they will be able to average the conditions over the month., B) No, they would need to collect data over a longer period of time., C) Yes, they will be able to tell if London is generally rainy or generally sunny., D) No, the differences between the first of the month and the last of the month will be too extreme. Stem: Which statement summarizes the LARGEST human impact on the carbon cycle and climate?
Choices: A) logging company removes all of the tall trees in a forested area., B) Humans are moving carbon from the atmosphere to the geosphere, decreasing global warming., C) Humans are moving carbon from the biosphere to the atmosphere, increasing global warming., D) Humans are moving carbon from the geosphere to the atmosphere, increasing global warming.
Scenario Justification: Real-world reference provides some context but limited uncertainty.
SEP Justification: No science practice engaged. Recall/identification only.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding relationships between science concepts.
CCC Justification: Multiple CCCs implicitly engaged through the reasoning required.

Stem: This question has two parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
